Catalytic CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is one of the important reactions for environmental-related applications. Pd/CeO2 catalysts with four different ceria morphologies, i.e. polyhedral, rod, cube and polygonal, and 5 wt% Pd loading were synthesized, and their catalytic characteristics and reaction mechanism were studied. Combining the results of N2 physisorption, XRD, Raman, CO2-TPD, Py-TPD and H2-TPR analyses suggests that PdO and PdxCe1−xO2-δ linkages are present in the Pd/CeO2 catalysts, which have different interactions with different exposed planes. Pd functionalized ceria with polyhedral morphology denoted as Pd/CeO2-NPH shows the highest specific surface area with exposed facets ({111}+{110}), responsible for the formation of more oxygen vacancy and higher extent of surface oxygen mobility, and higher number of acidic-basic sites on the catalysts surface, which contributed to improved catalytic activity and selectivity. XRD and Raman spectroscopy results revealed strong metal-support interactions for the most active catalyst by forming the PdxCe1−xO2-δ linkage, which improved the formation of surface oxygen vacancies and CO2 activation on the CeO2 support and promoted dissociation of H2 on the Pd metal. In-situ DRIFTS examination provided clear evidence for the formate reaction pathway of methanol synthesis. From a mechanistic point of view, the decomposition of surface carbonate species resulted in the formation of formate, which was further hydrogenated to form crucial methoxy species followed by methanol and CO as reaction products. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords CO2 hydrogenation to methanol Pd/CeO2 catalyst ceria morphology surface properties in-situ DRIFTS catalytic reaction mechanism investigation 1 Introduction Global CO2 emissions are rising sharply as a consequence of the extensive reliance on the combustion of fossil fuels for urbanization and industrial development in the period of prosperity. CO2 is not beneficial to the atmosphere, as it is marked as a greenhouse gas with severe detrimental environmental impacts like climate change, acidification of oceans, and so forth. Therefore, recycling of CO2 to industrially valued products and carbon-neutral fuels like methanol through the hydrogenation reaction is the most prominent option [1,2]. Over the last few decades, the ternary Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst system has been extensively explored in industries for CO2 hydrogenation; nevertheless, an excess of water formation leads to limited activity and poor selectivity as well as sintering of active phase with the resulting catalyst deactivation through the parasitic reverse water gas-shift reaction [3–5]. Commercially used Al2O3 carriers have proved to be catalytically inactive and only act as a support for the dispersion of Cu- and Zn-containing phases [6]. In contrast, the use of CeO2 support often reported superior methanol synthesis performance due to its oxygen storage capacity and unique, strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) [7–9]. Moreover, oxygen storage capacity and redox properties of ceria can easily be tuned by shuttling between Ce(IV) and Ce(III), which can lead to the formation of nonstoichiometric CeO2−x, consequently resulting in higher extent of surface oxygen vacancies [8]. Due to these unique properties, ceria-based catalysts have also been explored for several other catalytic applications, such as oxidation of VOC [10,11], CO [12–15], CO-PROX [16], propene [17] and soot [18], RWGS reaction [19], fuel cells [20], etc. Heterogeneously catalyzed reactions occur only at the surface of the catalyst; hence, the use of the nanosized catalyst, nanoparticles in the size <100 nm, to maximize the surface-to-volume ratio is preferred. Larger nanoparticles, in sizes of several dozen nanometers, tend to develop a well-distinct morphology; the ability to tailor the exposed planes of the catalyst plays a crucial role in finely tuning the catalytic activity. The means and procedures for designing the morphology of ceria nanoparticles are well described. Aneggi et al. [21] reported the hydrothermal synthesis and soot oxidation performance of ceria nanoparticles with cubic {100}, anisotropic (rods) ({100}, {110} and {111}), and octahedral {111} morphology. The study elucidated that soot oxidation reaction is a surface dependent reaction, with superior soot oxidation activity for CeO2 in the form of cubes and rods morphology compared to the octahedral nanoparticles, leading to the conclusion that the exposed planes are responsible for altering the catalytic activity. Further, CeO2 with rod, cube and irregularly-shaped particle morphology were investigated for reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS); it was found that ceria cubes with exposed {100} crystalline plane show superior activity compared to ceria rods and particles that exposed the {111} crystalline plane [19]. Si et al. investigated Au/CeO2 catalysts for RWGS reaction and found that CeO2 rods with {100} and {110} crystalline planes were the most active [22]. They have concluded that Au particles are stabilized and activated on the exposed planes, which contributes to the improved activity. Regarding CuO/CeO2 solids, it was found that CeO2 rods with {100} and {110} facets can enable higher dispersion of active Cu phase on the support and consequently superior catalytic N2O decomposition activity [23]. Furthermore, several theoretical and experimental studies proved that the exposed planes are responsible for the oxygen vacancies formation energy which ranked as {110} <{100} <{111} [24–28]. Palladium (Pd) is suggested as the active metal for the hydrogenation of CO and CO2 with improved activity, selectivity, and lifetime for methanol synthesis [7,29–37]. Ma et al. investigated Pd/CeO2 catalysts for methanol synthesis from syngas in the presence of sulfur [38]. They found that Pd/CeO2 catalysts showed excellent stability with improved catalytic CO2 hydrogenation performance. However, several studies reported the effect of morphology and the exposed crystalline facets of Pd/CeO2 catalysts for different catalytic applications. Hu et al. investigated Pd/CeO2 catalysts with different morphology and the effect of crystalline planes on catalytic CO and propane oxidation [39]. They found that the Pd/CeO2-rod catalyst with {110} and {100} crystalline planes showed the highest CO oxidation activity, which was due to low oxygen vacancy formation energy. However, the Pd/CeO2-octahedron with {111} crystalline planes with high oxygen vacancy formation energy consequently resulted in strong surface Ce-O bond formation, which improved propane oxidation. Further, Carraro et al. investigated the effect of morphology (cube and rod (small and long)) of Pd/CeO2 catalysts for the formation of syngas through the decomposition of methanol [40]. The Pd/CeO2 small rods with {100} crystalline planes showed the best methanol decomposition activity, which could be due to the improved interaction between the metal and the support. Recently, Jiang et al. investigated Pd/CeO2 catalysts with different morphology for catalytic CO2 hydrogenation, and confirmed that the rod with {110} and {111} crystalline planes showed the best catalytic CO2 hydrogenation activity, mainly facilitated due to the higher surface oxygen mobility and lowest oxygen vacancy energy [41]. To date, several studies have reported about Pd/CeO2 catalysts for methanol synthesis from CO2 hydrogenation, and their SMSI and morphology effect in the process. However, there is still a lack of clear evidence on how the morphology influences surface properties and catalytic performance by altering the formation of reaction intermediates. Herein, we synthesized the nanostructured ceria supports of different morphologies (i.e., polyhedral, rods, cubes, and polygonal particles) using hydrothermal and co-precipitation methods. Pd deposition on ceria supports was conducted by using the wet-impregnation method. To investigate morphological and surface properties of the synthesized CeO2 and Pd/CeO2 samples, the following characterization methods were used: SEM, SEM-EDXS, TEM, XRD, N2 physisorption, Raman spectroscopy, and temperature programed techniques (Py-TPD, CO2-TPD, H2-TPR). In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in-situ DRIFTS) study was conducted to investigate in detail the plausible reaction mechanism, and shed light on the correlation between different morphology, exposed crystalline planes and catalytic activity, selectivity, and formation of intermediates during the reaction under consideration. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All the chemicals used for the synthesis were of analytical grade and used without further purification. Cerium (III) nitrate hexahydrate ([Ce(NO3)3 × 6H2O], p.a., ≥99.0%) was purchased from Sigma Aldrich for the synthesis of cerium oxide supports. Ammonia hydroxide (NH4OH) (25%) solution and sodium hydroxide (NaOH) pellets (99.0% purity) were purchased from Merck, Germany. Palladium (II) nitrate dehydrate (Pd(NO3)2 ×2 H2O, 40% Pd) was purchased from Sigma Aldrich. The ELGA PURELAB FLEX instrument was utilized for the preparation of ultrapure water used for the synthesis of materials. Ultra-high pure reaction gas mixture (CO2 (24 vol%), H2 (72 vol%), bal. N2, Linde), H2 (99.999% purity), and N2 gas (99.999% purity) were used. 2.2 Synthesis of ceria supports 2.2.1 Synthesis of CeO2 polyhedral particles CeO2 nanoshaped polyhedral particles were synthesized by the hydrothermal method [23]. Ce(NO3)3 × 6H2O (1.24 g, 0.00286 mol) and NaOH (2.25 g, 0.05625 mol) were dissolved in 21.87 and 9.37 ml of distilled water, respectively, at room temperature. The mixture was allowed to stir for 60 min, followed by transfer to the Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor, and it was then aged for 24 h at 90 ºC. The obtained suspension was washed with distilled water and centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 10 min to remove the sodium ions. The precipitate was dried at 90 ºC for 12 h followed by calcination at 400 ºC for 3 h. 2.2.2 Synthesis of CeO2 rods and cubes The hydrothermal method was adopted for the synthesis of nanosized ceria rods and cubes [23]. Ce(NO3)3 × 6H2O (1.225 g, 0.002834 mol) and NaOH (13.45 g, 0.33625 mol) were dissolved in 21.87 and 35.96 ml of distilled water, respectively. Both the solutions were mixed and stirred vigorously for 60 min at room temperature. The resulting mixture was transferred to the Teflon-lined stainless steel reactor and aged for 24 h at 100 and 180ºC for rods and cubes, respectively. The obtained suspension was washed with distilled water and centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 10 min until pH reached the value of 7 to remove the sodium ions. The obtained precursor was dispersed in 10 ml of distilled water followed by freeze quenching using liquid N2 and dried for 24 h in a freeze dryer. The obtained powder was calcined at 400ºC for 4 h. 2.2.3 Synthesis of CeO2 polygonal particles Ceria with the nanostructured polygonal morphology was synthesized by means of the precipitation method [23]. Ce(NO3)3 × 6 H2O (1.25 g, 0.00290 mol) was dissolved in 50 ml of distilled water and stirred for 30 min. The NH4OH (5% v/v) solution was added dropwise to the aqueous solution of ceria salt until the pH value of the solution reached 9–10, under continuous stirring at room temperature. The resulting precipitate was aged for 3 h, followed by washing with distilled water until the pH value of the solution reached 7. The obtained precipitate was dried at 80 ºC for 12 h followed by calcination at 400 ºC for 3 h. 2.3 Synthesis of Pd/CeO2 catalysts The wet impregnation method was adopted to prepare Pd/CeO2 catalysts (5 wt% nominal loading of Pd). The desired amount of Pd(NO3)2 × 2 H2O aqueous solution was added to a CeO2 powder, and this slurry was stirred continuously for 1 h at room temperature. After impregnation, the sample was stirred at 60 °C temperature for 6 h, and the obtained dried powder was finally calcined at 400 °C for 2 h in the air atmosphere. 2.4 Characterization of catalysts Specific surface area, total pore volume, and pore size distribution were measured at −196 ºC by means of N2 physisorption using a TriStar II 3020 instrument from Micromeritics. Before measurements, samples were degassed using a Micromeritics’ SmartPrep degasser at 90ºC for 1 h, followed by heating at 180ºC for 4 h in N2 gas flow. The specific surface area was calculated by using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) method, while the Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) method was used to calculate the total pore volume and pore size distribution from desorption isotherms. Crystallinity and phase composition of the synthesized and spent catalysts were analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a PANalytical X'Pert Pro diffractometer with Cu Kα1 radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm). The catalysts were scanned in the 2θ range between 10° and 90°, with step increments of 0.05° and 100 s step time. The shape, size and the chemical composition of the catalysts were explored by scanning electron microscope (SEM, SUPRA 35VP, Carl Zeiss) equipped with energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDXS, Inca 400, Oxford Instruments). THE EDXS analysis was performed at 15 kV beam energy using the area scan mode. A transmission electron microscope (TEM, LaB6 JEM-2100, Jeol Inc.) operating at 200 kV was used to observe the shape and size of catalyst particles. The powdered samples were first dispersed in absolute ethanol and sonicated for 30 s to prevent agglomeration, and then transferred by drop-casting onto commercially available Ni-supported amorphous carbon grids. Such prepared samples were mounted in a beryllium analytical double-tilt holder. H2 temperature-programmed reduction of the samples was performed by using an AutoChem II 2920 apparatus from Micromeritics. 100 mg of a sample was placed on a quartz wool flock in a U-shaped quartz tube. The sample was heated up to 200 °C and held at this temperature for 20 min to remove the surface impurities and then cooled to 30 °C. All the pretreatment steps were done in an inert argon stream (25 ml/min). The analysis was conducted by heating the sample up to 800 °C, with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in a stream of 5% H2/Ar with a flow rate of 25 ml/min. CO2-TPD measurements were employed to measure the basicity of catalysts using the Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 apparatus connected to a mass spectrometer (Pfeiffer Vacuum, model ThermoStar™ GSD320). Prior to CO2 adsorption, catalysts were first reduced at 300 °C under H2 flow (20 ml/min) for 2 h and then brought to room temperature under argon flushing fu(25 ml/min) for 15 min. The reduced samples were then saturated with 20 pulses of 80% CO2/Ar mixture at 50 °C. Afterwards, TPD (temperature-programmed desorption) analysis was prompted with a heating rate of 10 °C/min under argon flow (15 ml/min), and desorbed CO2 was detected by means of the mass spectrometer. The amount of desorbed CO2 was calculated by comparing the integrated peak area of CO2-TPD curve to the area of the CO2 calibration pulse. The synthesized catalysts were investigated to determine the total amount of acidic sites by using the Perkin Elmer Pyris 1 TGA instrument, where pyridine was used as a probe. The synthesized catalysts were placed in a sample pan and pretreated at 380 °C in nitrogen flow (50 ml/min) for 15 min. The catalysts were then cooled to 120 °C and further saturated with pyridine vapor in nitrogen flow until the constant weight was observed. The catalysts saturated with pyridine were then treated in N2 flow (50 ml/min) at 120 °C to remove weakly adsorbed pyridine. The catalysts were then heated to 400 °C, with a heating rate of 20 °C/min in N2 flow (50 ml/min). Desorption of pyridine was recorded as a function of temperature. The catalysts were characterized by Raman spectroscopy using a WiTec Alpha 300 RA instrument. The spectra were recorded using laser intensity of 1.5 mW, with a wavelength of 532 nm. The laser beam was focused by 50× objective lens with a numerical aperture of 0.80. The obtained spectra were fitted with the Lorentz function fit to determine the Raman shift and area of peaks. The catalysts were examined after catalytic runs (spent catalysts) in order to determine the extent of carbon deposition on the surface of catalysts by using a CHNS analyzer (Perkin Elmer, model 2400 Series II). Structure stability of spent catalysts was also analyzed by using thermogravimetric temperature-programed oxidation (PerkinElmer, model STA 6000) from 50 to 800 °C, with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in a flow of air (50 ml/min). 2.5 In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) The in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra were recorded by using a FTIR spectrometer (Perkin Elmer, model Frontier), which is equipped with a mercury cadmium telluride detector (MCT) and a high-temperature high-pressure DRIFTS reaction cell (PIKE Technology). The sample was placed in an alumina crucible in the DRIFTS cell. All the spectra were recorded in the range of 4000–400 cm−1, with a resolution of 4 cm−1. Prior to the reaction, catalysts were reduced at 300 °C for 2 h under 15% H2/N2 flow at atmospheric pressure. The catalysts were then flushed for 1 h with N2 gas to remove hydrogen adsorbed on the catalyst surface. Subsequently, temperature was decreased to 260 °C and pressure was set to 50 bar (i.e. 5 MPa) under the flow of reaction gas (CO2:H2, 1:3) for 90 min to perform the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. In addition, pure CO2 adsorption experiments were conducted at atmospheric pressure at various temperatures. 2.6 Catalytic activity and selectivity measurements Catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 was performed using a fixed-bed steady-state catalytic reactor (PID Eng&Tech, Spain), equipped with a temperature controlled furnace, mass flow control, gas mixture chamber, pressure controller, and a GC instrument for online analysis. 50 mg of a catalyst diluted with 200 mg of SiC was loaded at the center of the stainless steel reactor tube with the help of an inserted stainless steel frit (2 µm pores). Prior to the hydrogenation reactions, the catalysts were reduced at 50 bar in a flow of H2 gas (15% H2, balanced with N2) with a flow rate of 100 ml/min at 300 °C for 2 h. After reduction the catalyst was cooled to the reaction temperature and purged with the reaction mixture gas (CO2:H2 = 1:3; 24 vol% CO2, 72 vol% H2 and 4 vol% N2) with a flow rate of 50 ml/min (GHSV: 60,000 h−1). The catalyst was tested at 200, 220, 240, and 260 °C at 50 bar pressure for 2 h at each temperature. Both the reactants and products were analyzed by means of an online gas chromatograph (Agilent Technologies, model 7890A) equipped with Porapak Q, HayeSep Q, and MS5A columns and two TCD detectors. CO2 conversion, CH3OH and CO selectivity, and space time yield (STY) of methanol were calculated as follows: C O 2 conversion % = n C O 2 in − n C O 2 out n C O 2 in × 100 C H 3 OH selectivity % = n C H 3 OH out n C O 2 in − n C O 2 out × 100 CO selectivity % = n CO out n C O 2 in − n C O 2 out × 100 C H 3 OH STY g g cat . × h = F C O 2 in × X C O 2 × S C H 3 OH × MW C H 3 OH W cat . × 100 n[CO2]in is the amount (in moles) of CO2 at the reactor inlet, n[CO2]out stands for the amount of CO2 at the reactor outlet, n[CH3OH]out is the amount of CH3OH at the reactor outlet, n[CO]out is the amount of CO at the reactor outlet, FCO2,in is the molar flow rate, XCO2 represents CO2 conversion, SCH3OH is the selectivity of methanol, and Wcat. is the weight of catalyst used. It should be noted that all the examined catalysts were evaluated twice (and the best performing catalyst three times) in order to make sure about the reliability of obtained activity and selectivity results. The best performing catalyst was further analyzed to determine the effect of pressure and gas flow rate on CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Moreover, it was also analyzed for long-term performance in order to determine its durability and activity in the time on stream period of 100 h. The spent catalyst was afterwards analyzed by means of XRD and CHNS techniques. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Figs. S1a and b illustrate the results of N2 physisorption analysis of as-synthesized nanoshaped pristine CeO2 and Pd/CeO2 catalysts for polyhedral, rod, cube, and polygonal morphology (hereafter denoted as CeO2-NPH and Pd/CeO2-NPH for polyhedral, CeO2-NR and Pd/CeO2-NR for rod, CeO2-NC and Pd/CeO2-NC for cube, and CeO2-NPG and Pd/CeO2-NPG for polygonal morphology). The specific surface area, total pore volume, and average pore diameter of the as-synthesized catalysts are summarized in Table 1. The different morphologies showed a considerable difference in the BET surface area (the following trend was observed: CeO2-NPH > CeO2-NR > CeO2-NPG > CeO2-NC), which agrees with the reported results from various research studies [23,42]. The addition of Pd ensembles on the ceria support shows a slight decrease in the values of specific surface area as a consequence of pore blockage [43–45]. All calcined CeO2 samples and Pd/CeO2 catalysts show the typical type IV narrow hysteresis loop with H2 type curve (IUPAC classification), indicating a mesoporous structure with interparticle porosity [46]. Fig. S2 shows XRD patterns for the as-synthesized nanoshaped CeO2 and Pd/CeO2 catalysts calcined in an air atmosphere at 400 °C for 4 and 3 h, respectively. The characteristic peaks correspond to pure CeO2 with cubic fcc structure (Fm-3m, S.G. 225) (ICDD PDF # 34-0394). All the catalysts exhibit sharp and very intense characteristic peaks at 28.58, 33.03, 47.48, 56.28, 59.08, 69.28, 76.58, 78.93, and 88.89° for the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), (420), and (422) reflection planes, respectively. The average crystallite size of catalysts estimated by using the Scherrer equation was in the range of 10–23 nm, as shown in Table 1. The CeO2-NPH sample with the crystallite size of 11 nm exhibits the highest BET specific surface area. The average crystallite size for CeO2-NR, CeO2-NPG, and CeO2-NC solids was calculated as 12, 13, and 23 nm, respectively. After loading of Pd, virtually the same XRD patterns with no peaks related to Pd (39.5°) and PdO (34.03 and 55°) or other oxide phases were observed. This can be a consequence of low Pd loading and/or high dispersion of Pd on CeO2 supports. The addition of Pd has hardly been showing any changes in the crystal structure of ceria, however a slight contraction of the lattice was observed as shown in Table 1. As in more detail, Pd+2 has a smaller ionic radius (86 pm) than Ce+4 (111 pm), thus allowing the entry of Pd into the lattice of Ce via substitutional doping, which might result in formation of PdxCe1-xO2-δ [47]. This was confirmed below by the results of Raman spectroscopy measurements. The SEM (Fig. S3) and TEM observations ( Fig. 1) of the as-synthesized pristine CeO2 supports showed distinctive morphological differences between the samples, while the phase composition analysis by selective area electron diffraction (SAED) corresponds to single-phase fcc CeO2 in all cases (Fig. S5). In the case of CeO2-NPH sample, the individual particles are 10–60 nm in size, with well-developed but distinct morphology, best described as an irregular polyhedral morphology, along with some small rods with different ratios with predominant {111} and {110} facets (Fig. 1a and b). The particles of the sample CeO2-NR are highly anisotropic, 50–205 nm in length, with an average diameter of about 10 nm. The morphology of these rod-like particles is dominated by {111} and {100} facets (Fig. 1c and d). The CeO2-NC material consists of nanoparticles exhibiting a cubic morphology with {100} facets, with the overall size of particles in the range of 15–55 nm, with an average particle size of ∼20 nm (Fig. 1e and f). A small but noticeable fraction of truncated nanocubes was also observed. The ceria synthesized by the co-precipitation method (CeO2-NPG) has a wide particle size distribution of 3–40 nm, with an irregular polygonal morphology of particles with dominating {111} plane (Fig. 1g and h). Figs. S4 and 2 show SEM as well as TEM and HR-TEM images of Pd/CeO2 catalysts of different morphology. The addition of Pd ensembles shows virtually the same morphology as pristine CeO2 support. In case of CeO2-NPH and Pd/CeO2-NPG samples, it is difficult to distinguish the Pd and/or PdO particles from the CeO2 particles. However, Pd/CeO2-NR and Pd/CeO2-NC solids show the lattice fringes of 2.6 and 3.0 Å, which corresponds to PdO {002} and {111} planes. The size of Pd nanoparticles was found to be around 5–8 nm. It should be noted that the Pd particle size was estimated from single particles, because the calculation of Pd size distribution is difficult due to the incorporation of Pd in the lattice of CeO2. Moreover, SEM-EDXS analysis was used to confirm the presence of Pd on the CeO2 support, being in the range of 4.4–4.6 wt% (Table 1). Raman spectra of CeO2 supports and Pd/CeO2 catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 3. All the as-synthesized pristine CeO2 supports show a strong peak at 465 cm−1, attributed to F2 g mode, and three weak peaks at 260, 598, and 1175 cm−1, attributed to second-order transverse acoustic (2TA) mode, defect-induce (D) mode, and second-order longitudinal optical (2LO) mode, respectively [47,48]. It should be noted that the particle sizes of CeO2 supports are closely related to the Raman shift and full width half maxima (FWHM) of F2 g peak [49–51]. The deposition of Pd on CeO2 shows a noticeable change in the Raman shift and FWHM of F2 g peak for all the catalysts. The trend of Raman shift was observed as follows: Pd/CeO2-NPH (458 cm−1) < Pd/CeO2-NR (462 cm−1) = Pd/CeO2-NPG (462 cm−1) < Pd/CeO2-NC (465 cm−1), and the trend of FWHM of F2 g peak is the following: Pd/CeO2-NPH (33.56 cm−1) ≅ Pd/CeO2-NR (34 cm−1) = Pd/CeO2-NPG (19.38 cm−1) < Pd/CeO2-NC (15.92 cm−1). The trend observed in the Raman shift and FWHM of F2 g peak could reflect the smallest particle size of Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst, as confirmed by the TEM investigation. Moreover, two new peaks were observed at 650 and 835 cm−1 that correspond to the vibration mode of PdO and Pd-O-CeO2 (formed due to the interaction of Pd and CeO2), respectively [39]. The peaks were fitted by a peak fitting tool and the ratio of Id/IF2 g was determined by integrating the peaks, reflecting the defects concentration. The trend concerning Id/IF2 g for the pristine CeO2 was observed as follows (Table S1): CeO2-NPH (0.035) > CeO2-NR (0.027) > CeO2-NPG (0.02) > CeO2-NC (0.016). The addition of Pd shows a noticeable increase in the Id/IF2 g ratio, however it follows the same trend as obtained for pristine ceria samples: Pd/CeO2-NPH (0.40) > Pd/CeO2-NR (0.37) > Pd/CeO2-NPG (0.3) > Pd/CeO2-NC (0.25). Moreover, the wavenumber difference between F2 g and d peaks is ∼138 nm, indicating the generation of intrinsic oxygen vacancy due to the redox couple between Ce+4-Ce+3 [52,53]. These observations are in agreement with the results of XRD analysis, which alluded to the contraction of ceria lattice and formation of PdxCe1-xO2-δ. The latter might be responsible for the formation of more oxygen defects in comparison to PdO species on the surface of CeO2 in case of all four catalysts. The as-synthesized catalysts were investigated for their reduction behavior by using the H2-TPR technique. Fig. 4 depicts the obtained H2-TPR curves for pristine CeO2 and Pd/CeO2 samples of different morphology. For all pristine CeO2 supports (CeO2-NPH, CeO2-NR, CeO2-NC and CeO2-NPG), two types of reduction peaks were observed (Fig. 4a), which are consistent with the available reports. The peaks observed in the range of 300–600 °C are attributed to the reduction of surface oxygen of ceria, while the peaks observed above 700 °C belong to the reduction of bulk ceria to Ce2O3 [39,54,55]. The H2 consumption was calculated by integrating the measured peaks, and the following trend was obtained: CeO2-NPH (1.151 mmol/g) > CeO2-NR (1.08 mmol/g) > CeO2-NPG (0.926 mmol/g) > CeO2-NC (0.395 mmol/g). The highest H2 consumption was observed for the CeO2-NPH support, which actually is in good agreement with the highest specific surface area and mobility of available surface oxygen. Fig. 4b depicts reduction peaks for Pd/CeO2 samples with different morphologies. All the calcined Pd/CeO2 catalysts (Pd/CeO2-NPH, Pd/CeO2-NR, Pd/CeO2-NC and Pd/CeO2-NPG) exhibited reduction peaks below 0 °C, which is attributed to the reduction of PdO species to Pd0 [56]. It is known that PdO species undergo reduction in the presence of gaseous H2 below 0 °C, which results in the formation of βPdH. Notably, sharp negative peaks were observed in the TPR profiles at 64, 61, 63, and 61 °C for Pd/CeO2-NPH, Pd/CeO2-NR, Pd/CeO2-NC and Pd/CeO2-NPG samples, respectively, which is assigned to the decomposition of βPdH [57]. Fig. 4c further depicts the enlarged part of catalyst reduction occurring in the temperature range of 75–500 °C. It should be noted that Pd/CeO2-NPH, Pd/CeO2-NR, Pd/CeO2-NPG, and Pd/CeO2-NC catalysts exhibit surface reduction peaks at 381, 384, 389, and 433 °C, respectively, which are positioned at remarkably lower temperatures than in pristine CeO2 supports, and ascribed to the improved availability of surface oxygen as a consequence of the deposition of Pd on the ceria support. However, we calculated H2 consumption of Pd/ceria only in the temperature range of 200–500 °C by integrating the corresponding peaks, which follow the same trend as in the case of ceria supports: Pd/CeO2-NPH (0.353 mmol/g) > Pd/CeO2-NR (0.319 mmol/g) > Pd/CeO2-NPG (0.292 mmol/g) > Pd/CeO2-NC (small hump was observed at 433 °C, however, the calculation of H2 consumption is not possible due to the very low reduction peak, which is below the detection limit). Pd/CeO2-NPG and Pd/CeO2-NC samples show an additional peak in the range of 200–250 °C that could be due to the reduction of strongly bonded Pd species with CeO2-O species [57]. The results confirmed the obvious effect of morphology on the reduction behavior of CeO2 supports and Pd/CeO2 catalysts. The Pd/CeO2-NPH sample shows the highest extent of reduction compared to Pd/CeO2-NR, Pd/CeO2-NPG, and Pd/CeO2-NC catalysts, which could be due to strong interaction of Pd ensembles and CeO2 by forming PdxCe1-xO2-δ. The results are consistent with the findings of Raman spectroscopy analysis. Moreover, higher reducibility of Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst could be due to the highest surface area and morphology, which promotes the formation of oxygen defects. The strength and quantity of surface basic sites of pristine CeO2 supports and Pd/CeO2 catalysts of different morphology were investigated by using CO2-TPD-MS analysis ( Fig. 5). All the pristine CeO2 and Pd/CeO2 calcined catalysts show CO2 desorption peaks categorized in three different groups appearing at 50–200, 200–450, and 450–800 °C, which are ascribed to weak, moderate, and strong basic sites. The obtained values of desorption capacity are summarized in Table S1. The CeO2-NPH catalyst shows the highest CO2 desorption with a large quantity of basic sites (0.60 mmol/g), followed by CeO2-NR (0.56 mmol/g), CeO2-NPG (0.47 mmol/g), and CeO2-NC (0.32 mmol/g) solids. All pristine CeO2 supports exhibit a large peak above room temperature, with the desorption maxima around ∼90 °C, which is assigned to the weak basic sites. However, peak tailing was observed in the range of 195–205 °C for CeO2-NPH, CeO2-NR, and CeO2-NPG samples, and around 250 °C for CeO2-NC solid. The trend of CO2 desorption follows the same trend as variations in specific surface area among these samples. All the results of CO2 desorption are consistent with the reported findings [58,59]. It is worth mentioning that the addition of Pd on the CeO2 support shows a noticeable change in the strength and quantity of basic sites. All Pd/CeO2 catalysts showed an additional peak in the temperature range of moderate basic sites, i.e. from 200 to 450 °C, which is the active temperature range for catalytic CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. For illustration, Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst shows the highest CO2 desorption (0.95 mmol/g), followed by Pd/CeO2-NR (0.92 mmol/g), Pd/CeO2-NPG (0.51 mmol/g), and Pd/CeO2-NC (0.37 mmol/g) samples. The addition of Pd shows a noticeable enhancement of basic sites in the case of Pd/CeO2-NPH and Pd/CeO2-NR samples, however this was less pronounced for Pd/CeO2-NGP and Pd/CeO2-NC solids. Further, an interesting correlation was observed from the CO2-TPD results when taking into account specific surface area and morphology of Pd/CeO2 samples. The Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst, with the highest specific surface area and {111} and {110} facets, shows the highest CO2 adsorption capacity, followed by the Pd/CeO2-NR catalyst, with slightly lower surface area and terminated by {111} and {100} planes. Further, the Pd/CeO2-NGP sample with {111} facets shows higher CO2 adsorption capacity compared to the Pd/CeO2-NC solid with {100} facets. The theoretical study [60] suggests that {100} facets are more active than {111} facets for adsorption and activation of CO2; however, in the present study, the influence of specific surface area is more pronounced than the nature of exposed crystal facets, which is also confirmed below by in-situ DRIFT investigation (see Figs. 10–12 and S7–S9). The number of acidic sites of CeO2 supports and Pd/CeO2 catalysts of different morphology were investigated by using the Py-TPD technique. Fig. 6 depicts the obtained Py-TPD curves. CeO2-NPH and CeO2-NPG samples show low extent of pyridine desorption in the range of 120–400 °C; however, CeO2-NR and CeO2-NC materials exhibit negligible presence of acidic sites. Addition of Pd-containing species shows the modification of the catalyst surface by generation of acidic site. Within an experimental error, in the range of 250–375 °C, samples Pd/CeO2-NPH, Pd/CeO2-NR, and Pd/CeO2-NPG show almost the same number of acidic sites, followed by the Pd/CeO2-NC catalyst. This is in good agreement with the reported results [58]. In the case of Pd/CeO2-NR catalyst, a small shift of the pyridine desorption peak to lower temperature (i.e. a decrease of strength of acidic sites) was observed. Nevertheless, it is obvious that the difference in the morphology and the exposed facets shows a clear impact on the strength and quantity of acidic sites in examined solids. CO2-TPD and Py-TPD profiles reveal that the addition of Pd enhances both basicity and acidity of Pd/CeO2 catalysts (Table S1). However, it is further obvious from Table S1 that the examined CeO2 supports and Pd/CeO2 catalysts contain almost an order of magnitude lower number of acidic sites compared to the number of basic sites. 3.2 Catalytic CO2 hydrogenation Catalytic performance of all the as-synthesized Pd/CeO2 catalysts with different morphologies was investigated in the process of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol at 50 bar total pressure in the temperature range of 200–260 °C, with a flow of 50 ml/min of reaction gas (CO2:H2, 1:3). Fig. 7a-d and Table S2(a-d) depict the measured dependencies and values for catalytic CO2 conversion, selectivity for CO and methanol, and space time yield (STY) of methanol for Pd/CeO2 calcined catalysts. Pristine CeO2 supports of different morphology were investigated in the same range of operating and reaction conditions and found to be inactive in the reaction under consideration. However, addition of Pd to CeO2 shows quite interesting promotional activity, with a drastic enhancing of the catalytic performance of CO2 hydrogenation. As in more detail, the Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst shows the highest CO2 conversion at all temperatures compared to the other catalysts, with a linear trend. The highest CO2 conversions obtained at 200–260 °C were found to be in the range of 4.3–8.7%. In the same temperature range, Pd/CeO2-NR, Pd/CeO2-NPG, and Pd/CeO2-NC samples showed CO2 conversions between 3.2% and 7.3%, 3.5–7.4%, and 3.9–6.5%, respectively (Fig. 7a and Table S2(a-d)). It should be noted that at 200 °C, the Pd/CeO2-NR catalyst showed the lowest CO2 conversion, however it improved at 220 °C in comparison to Pd/CeO2-NPG and Pd/CeO2-NC solids. Further, at 260 °C, the Pd/CeO2-NR and Pd/CeO2-NPG catalysts showed almost the same activity; however, the Pd/CeO2-NC sample showed the lowest CO2 conversion among all examined catalysts. The Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst showed the lowest selectivity, and the Pd/CeO2-NC sample exhibited the highest selectivity for CO (Fig. 7b). The observed trend for CO selectivity was as follows: Pd/CeO2-NPH < Pd/CeO2-NR < Pd/CeO2-NPG < Pd/CeO2-NC. The Pd/CeO2-NPH, Pd/CeO2-NR, Pd/CeO2-NPG, and Pd/CeO2-NC samples showed CO selectivity of 33.0–23.2, 34.3–25.1, 53.2–30.1, and 100–49.9%, respectively, at reaction temperatures between 200 and 260 °C (Table S2). All the catalysts show the highest CO selectivity at 200 °C; however, with an increased reaction temperature, the selectivity to CO decreased and almost the same values were observed for all the catalysts at 240 and 260 °C. Several studies reported that at low temperatures, Pd is active for the decomposition of methanol and formation of CO and H2 by breaking the C-H bond. The studies also demonstrated that supported Pd nanoparticles are highly active towards the reverse water gas shift reaction [61]. Fig. 7c depicts CH3OH selectivity for all the Pd/CeO2 as-synthesized catalysts. The trend for CH3OH selectivity was observed as follows: Pd/CeO2-NPH > Pd/CeO2-NR > Pd/CeO2-NPG > Pd/CeO2-NC, which is exactly reverse to the obtained CO selectivity trend described above. The Pd/CeO2-NPH sample shows the highest selectivity for methanol with 67–77%, followed by Pd/CeO2-NR, Pd/CeO2-NPG, and Pd/CeO2-NC catalysts, i.e. 65.7–74.9%, 46.7–69.9%, and 0–68.5%, respectively, in the temperature range of 200–260 °C. It should be noted that the Pd/CeO2-NC catalyst shows zero selectivity at 200 °C and lowest selectivity for methanol among all morphologies. Fig. 7d and Table S2(a-d) provide the values of space time yield (STY) of methanol for Pd/CeO2 catalysts. The same trend is observed as in the case of methanol selectivity, i.e. Pd/CeO2-NPH > Pd/CeO2-NR > Pd/CeO2-NPG > Pd/CeO2-NC. The values of STY of CH3OH show a linear trend for Pd/CeO2-NPH, Pd/CeO2-NR, and Pd/CeO2-NPG catalysts; however, the Pd/CeO2-NC sample showed a damped trend as the temperature increased, which could be due to the catalyst thermodynamic limitation for methanol formation. Fig. 8 depicts CO2 conversion, CO and methanol selectivity, and STY of methanol of all the Pd/CeO2 catalysts with different morphologies. The Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst shows the highest CO2 conversion, higher selectivity for methanol, and high STY of methanol, accompanied with the lowest selectivity for CO. Further, Fig. 9 depicts that increased acidity-basicity of catalysts resulted in an increase of catalytic activity. Higher basicity of the catalyst surface increases the number of active sites for CO2 adsorption and activation, which enhances the catalytic activity. Furthermore, it is believed that higher acidity of the catalyst surface could increase STY of methanol via stabilization of the -HCOO intermediate [62], which is in agreement with the proposed reaction mechanism described in Section 3.4. Nevertheless, since the number of acidic sites on the surface of examined catalysts is about an order of magnitude lower than the number of basic sites (Table S1), one can reasonably assume that the catalytic activity is predominantly influenced by the basicity of the materials. In addition to the above, morphology influences acidity-basicity of examined catalysts, which alters their catalytic performance. The Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst with exposed {111} and {110} facets shows the highest CO2 conversion, with improved CH3OH selectivity and the lowest selectivity for CO. However, the Pd/CeO2-NR sample with {111} and {100} planes exhibits slightly decreased catalytic activity. Further, Pd/CeO2-NPG {111} and Pd/CeO2-NC {100} catalysts were found as the least active in the process of CO2 hydrogenation. This can be explained by considering the trend for the energy of formation of oxygen vacancy for ceria is, in terms of exposed crystalline planes, as follows: {110} <{100} <{111} [63]. The trend for CO2 conversion, CH3OH selectivity, and STY of methanol is as follows: Pd/CeO2-NPH ({111}+{110}) > Pd/CeO2-NR ({111}+{100}) > Pd/CeO2-NPG {111} > Pd/CeO2-NC {100}. The formation energy for oxygen vacancy for {111} plane is higher than the one for {100} plane and consequently results in less oxygen vacancy. However, the Pd/CeO2-NPG {111} sample shows slightly better activity compared to the Pd/CeO2-NC {100} solid, which shows the lowest activity among all the examined catalysts. This could be due to the lowest specific surface area and higher particle size, which is also reflected in the results of H2-TPR, CO2-TPD, Py-TPD, and Raman spectroscopy. The best performing Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst was further tested to examine an influence of different experimental parameters on its behavior. Fig. S6a and b present the values of CO2 conversion, methanol selectivity, CO selectivity, and STY of methanol obtained at different gas flow rates and total pressure. For gas flow rates of 40 and 50 ml/min, CO2 conversions are actually the same (most probably due to mass-transfer limitations present at the lower gas flow rate); however, slight decrease in methanol selectivity was observed. Further increase in the gas flow rate shows a significant decrease in CO2 conversion (due to lower residence time of gas phase in the catalytic bed) and higher selectivity for CO formation. This is very obvious, as the contact time of catalyst and reactant gas is decreased, which suggests that the formation of CO is an easier reaction path and independent of the morphology of Pd/CeO2 catalysts in comparison to methanol formation. In contrast, an increase of total pressure shows enhanced CO2 conversions. It should be noted that the increase of pressure favors the formation of methanol with low selectivity for CO. Steep increase in STY of methanol was observed as the pressure increased from 10 to 50 bar. It can therefore be concluded that increased reaction pressure drives the reaction equilibrium towards methanol formation. 3.3 In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) In-situ DRIFTS experiments were performed to understand the plausible reaction mechanism by identifying the possible intermediates formed on the catalyst surface during the synthesis of methanol through the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. Herein, we have selected pristine CeO2-supports and Pd/CeO2 catalysts with polyhedral and cube morphology to understand the reason for their different catalytic activity. 3.3.1 Adsorption of pure CO2 on CeO2 supports and Pd/CeO2 catalysts Pure CO2 adsorption behavior over the surface of pristine CeO2 supports and Pd/CeO2 catalysts (CeO2-NPH, Pd/CeO2-NPH, CeO2-NC and Pd/CeO2-NC) was investigated at atmospheric pressure in the temperature range of 50–260 °C (Fig. S7a and b, Fig. 10a and b). The CeO2-NPH sample shows peaks for bidentate carbonate (b-CO3 2-) at 1020–1081, 1304, and 1582 cm−1 and peaks of bridged carbonate species (br-CO3 2-) appearing at 1020–1082 and 1685 cm−1 at lower temperatures. As the temperature increased, the b-CO3 2- species decomposed and formed more stable monodentate carbonate species (m-CO3 2-) with peaks at 1020–1082, 1400, and 1580 cm−1. Additionally, formation of hydrogen carbonate species (HCO3 -) was observed with typical bands at 1020–1082, 1400, and 1217 cm−1, which is most probably due to the interaction of CeO2 with the surface OH groups. The CeO2-NC sample shows the same type of carbonate species with slight variation in the vibration frequency, which could be due to the difference in the atomic arrangement of the surface of different ceria nanoshapes [64,65]. For illustration, the CeO2-NC sample shows the presence of b-CO3 2- (1082, 1310 and 1612 cm−1), br-CO3 2- (1082 and 1685 cm−1), m-CO3 2- (1082, 1399 and 1612 cm−1), and HCO3 - (1082, 1400 and 1217 cm−1) species. Fig. 10a and b depict the DRIFTS spectra for pure CO2 gas adsorption on the surface of Pd/CeO2-NPH and Pd/CeO2-NC catalysts. At 50 and 100 °C, the Pd/CeO2-NPH sample shows peaks at 1015–1051, 1304, and 1582 cm−1 that correspond to the bidentate surface carbonate species (b-CO3 2-); however, increased temperature (150–260 °C) results in the decomposition of b-CO3 2- with formation of peaks at 1030–1082 and 1584 cm−1, which correspond to the monodentate carbonate species (m-CO3 2-). As the temperature increased, peaks at 1015–1084 and 1399 cm−1 were observed, which are attributed to the hydrogen carbonate (HCO3 -). These results are in good agreement with the reported studies, and further suggest that the interaction of surface ceria hydroxyl species with the adsorbed CO2 may result in the formation of HCO3 - [66,67]. Adsorption of pure CO2 over the Pd/CeO2-NC catalyst was also conducted. This catalyst shows the appearance of peaks belonging to b-CO3 2- (1073, 1323 and 1625 cm−1), m-CO3 2- (1062, 1302, 1399 and 1584–1542 cm−1), and HCO3 - (1082, 1217 and 1399 cm−1) species, with slightly different vibration frequencies due to different atomic surface arrangements. The Pd/CeO2-NPH and Pd/CeO2-NC catalysts showed less intense peaks for the formate species, which disappeared with the increased temperature. However, formation of both HCO3 - and formate species are obvious when the catalysts were pretreated by using H2 gas. The surface lattice oxygen vacancies resulted in the formation of b-CO3 2-, br-CO3 2-, and m-CO3 2- on both nanoshaped morphologies [59]. The CO2-TPD profiles for CeO2 and Pd/CeO2 solids (Fig. 5) depict the peak at around 85–95 °C that was assigned to HCO3 -, which decomposed to form b-CO2 2- and m-CO3 2- at around 200–225 °C. Formation of b-CO3 2- and m-CO3 2- species was observed in both catalysts; however, the Pd/CeO2-NC sample showed less intensive peaks for b-CO3 2-, m-CO3 2-, and HCO3 - compared to the Pd/CeO2-NPH solid, owing to the different atomic arrangement on the surface, which consequently resulted in the variation of oxygen defects. 3.3.2 Reaction gas adsorption on CeO2 supports and Pd/CeO2 catalysts The pristine CeO2 supports and Pd/CeO2 catalysts (i.e. CeO2-NPH, Pd/CeO2-NPH, CeO2-NC and Pd/CeO2-NC) were investigated for adsorption of reaction gas (CO2/H2, 1:3) at 260 °C and 50 bar. Fig. S8a and b depict the DRIFTS spectra for pristine CeO2 supports that show typical peaks for the C-H stretching of formate species at 2940 and 2852 cm−1 [68]. The peaks of bi-formate species for different vibration modes were further observed at νas(OCO)–1580, δ(H-C)–1376, νs(OCO)–1355 cm−1, and νas(OCO)–1579, δ(H-C)–1384, νs(OCO)−1360 cm−1 for CeO2-NPH and CeO2-NC samples, respectively [68]. In addition to the above peaks, a weak peak was observed at 2716 cm−1 and assigned to the overtone 2δ(OCH) band of bi-formate. However, it should be noted that a peak for hydrogen bicarbonate was observed (at 1030 and 1020 cm−1 for CeO2-NPH and CeO2-NC samples, respectively), which slowly decomposed, and peaks for either bi-carbonate or p-carbonate species (at 1060 and 1081 cm−1 for CeO2-NPH and CeO2-NC samples, respectively). Besides, the peak for CO formation was also not observed in the case of both pristine ceria supports. In addition, the supports did not show any evidence of the formation of methanol vibration band. Fig. 11a and b illustrate the corresponding CO2/H2 adsorption spectra obtained for Pd/CeO2 samples by performing the experiment at 260 °C and 50 bar for 90 min. The Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst (Fig. 11a) shows typical peaks for the formate species, with different vibrational modes at νas(OCO)–1584, δ(H-C)–1389 and νs(OCO)–1354 cm−1. An additional peak at 2716 cm−1 was observed, which is assigned to the overtone 2δ(OCH) of formate. Typical peaks for methanol C-O stretching at 1010, 1033, and 1063 cm−1 were observed. The peak intensity for 1010 and 1033 cm−1 was increasing with increased time of exposure. The peaks observed at 2821, 2847, 2870, 2921, 2952, and 2979 cm−1 were assigned to the stretching of methanol C-H bond [69,70]. The weak peak at 3016 cm−1 observed only after 15 min might be assigned to the vibrational stretching of C-H bond of CH4. Interestingly, the methane formation peak was of very low intensity and even below the detection limit of GC analysis. The strong peak for surface adsorbed CO gas was observed at 2175 and 2110 cm−1, which is attributed to the RWGS reaction taking place [71]. The weak oscillating peaks observed at around 1400–1800 cm−1 were assigned to the presence of water vapor formed as a result of both methanol and RWGS reactions [71]. Fig. 11b shows in-situ DRIFTS spectra for the Pd/CeO2-NC catalyst. The latter also shows the presence of formate species (νas(OCO)–1579, δ(H-C)–1387 and νs(OCO)–1341 cm−1). The peaks corresponding to methanol C-O stretching were observed at 1032 and 1063 cm−1. The Pd/CeO2-NC sample also showed the peaks at 2824, 2856, 2870, 2923, 2953, and 2977 cm−1 that were assigned to the stretching of methanol C-H bond; however, intensity of peaks is much lower compared to the Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst. After one hour of the test, the methanol intensity peaks started to decrease, which might be due to the reverse water gas shift reaction, which proved to be favorable in case of exposed {100} crystalline planes [19]. Further, the Pd/CeO2-NC sample shows typical bands for surface adsorbed CO gas at 2175 and 2110 cm−1, which were more abundant compared to the corresponding peaks obtained in the case of Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst. The obtained results are in good agreement with the results of catalytic runs, where the Pd/CeO2-NC catalyst showed higher CO selectivity and lower methanol selectivity (Fig. 7). To shed more light on the correlation between the formation of reaction intermediates and methanol, we performed in-situ DRIFTS analysis at atmospheric pressure by flowing first pure CO2 for 30 min over the Pd/CeO2-NPH and Pd/CeO2-NC catalyst and then switched the gas flow to pure H2 at atmospheric pressure (Fig. S9a and b). It was confirmed in the previous experiment (Fig. 10a and b) that only b-CO3 2-, m-CO3 2-, and HCO3 - species were observed. However, as the CO2 flow was switched to H2 flow, the C-H (2953 and 2850–2830 cm−1), C-O (1582, 1372 and 1334 cm−1), and C-O (1609, 1374 and 1330 cm−1) vibration modes of formate species were observed, with a high intensity for Pd/CeO2-NPH and Pd/CeO2-NC catalysts, respectively. It should be noted that the intensity of formate peaks decreased with time, which might be due to the reduced CO2 concentration in the reaction chamber. The oscillating peaks between 1400 and 1800 cm−1 were obtained, which were attributed to water vapor formation due to the formate hydrogenation. There were no methoxy species detected during the reaction. Also, no CO was detected, which implies that the formation of CO is also dependent on total pressure of the reaction. It is worth mentioning that in the presence of Pd/CeO2-NC catalyst, a peak at 3016 cm−1 corresponding to methane was observed that might be due to the methanation reaction favorable over this catalyst with {100} exposed crystalline facets, which is consistent with the literature reports [72,73]. To confirm the same, the reaction was performed by flowing pure CO2 over the catalyst for 30 min and then switching the gas flow to H2 at 50 bar pressure (Fig. 12a and b). The Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst shows weak peaks corresponding to the C-H (2850 cm−1) and C-O (2856 cm−1) stretching of formate species observed after 1 min; however, these peaks started to get more intense after 5 min. In the same time period, peaks were also observed in the C-H (2982, 2949, 2925, 2865, 2853 and 2825 cm−1) and C-O (1063, 1033 and 1010 cm−1) regions belonging to the formation of methoxy species. Moreover, peaks confirming formation of water vapor were observed, which is due to the formate hydrogenation reaction. Finally, formation of methoxy species from the formate species is very crucial and rapid step. Intensity of the formate peak decreases, while the intensity of methoxy peak increases as a function of time. The CO formation peak was also visible after 15 min, unlike in the case of CO2 hydrogenation carried out at atmospheric pressure. The Pd/CeO2-NC catalyst showed weak intensity peaks for formate after 5 min; however, methoxy peak formation was observed after 15 min. It should be noted that the peak intensity for methanol was very low. The weak peaks were observed in the C-H (2979, 2958, 2928, 2865, 2862 and 2828 cm−1) region. It was noticeable that the C-O region peaks (1033 and 1010 cm−1) belonging to the formation of methoxy species were missing in the presence of Pd/CeO2-NC catalyst, which is consistent with the above results (see Fig. 11b). To summarize, the above-described in-situ DRIFTS experiments revealed that the activated CO2 can form carbonate intermediates (Fig. 10), which rapidly hydrogenate to the formate species followed by the subsequent hydrogenation to the methoxy species (Figs. 11 and 12). It should be noted that hydrogenation of formate to the methoxy species is a crucial step for methanol formation. Clear evidence about the rapid formation of methoxy species was obtained in the presence of Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst (Figs. 11a and 12a). On the contrary, slow formation and consequently weak intensity and/or absence of methoxy peaks was observed in case of Pd/CeO2-NC sample (Figs. 11b and 12b). 3.4 Plausible reaction mechanism based on DRIFTS study The mechanism of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol may vary in the presence of different catalysts. Based on the theoretical and experimental studies, extensive research has been done to investigate the reaction mechanism for methanol synthesis [41]. The two prime routes for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol have been reported: (a) CO formation via RWGS followed by syngas hydrogenation, and (b) formate route. The above-described in-situ DRIFTS experiments have provided all the essential evidence to understand the mechanism of methanol formation via CO2 hydrogenation reaction in the presence of Pd/CeO2 catalysts. For Pd/CeO2 system, CO2 is activated on the CeO2 surface, which is closely related to the surface oxygen vacancy, and Pd is responsible for the dissociation of H2 and spillover of ad-atoms to adsorbed CO2 molecule. Activation of CO2 on the CeO2 surface is morphology dependent, as demonstrated by the results of CO2-TPD and in-situ DRIFTS analyses (Figs. 5 and 10 and S7). Several investigations suggested that the formation of oxygen vacancy leads to the generation of two unpaired electrons, which are responsible for the reduction of Ce+4 to Ce+3. In turn, Ce+3 acts as a Lewis base site for the adsorption and activation of CO2, leading to the formation of active CO2 -δ species (HCO3 -, b-CO3 2-, br-CO3 2- and m-CO3 2-), which was confirmed by the in-situ DRIFTS experiments performed on both pristine CeO2 supports and Pd/CeO2 catalysts (Figs. 10 and S7) of different morphology. Different catalyst morphology with different exposed crystalline planes influenced the formation of intermediates, i.e. b-CO3 2-, m-CO3 2-, -HCO3 -, -HCOO, CO, CH3O-, and CH3OH species. However, after careful analysis of results of in-situ DRIFTS experiments, no intermediate for HCOOH was observed, which excludes the RWGS route and confirms that the reaction proceeds through the formate pathway. Therefore, the plausible mechanism for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol over the Pd/CeO2 catalysts can be described as follows: (i) activation of CO2 on Ce+3 sites of CeO2 support and formation of HCO3 - that decomposed to br-CO3 2- and b-CO3 2- species that further decompose to form the stable m-CO3 2- species; (ii) dissociation of H2 ad-species on Pd ensembles and spillover of H species from Pd to activated CO2 -δ species at the Pd/CeO2 interface; (iii) H ad-species react with m-CO3 2- species and undergo the hydrogenation reaction to form the formate species (m-HCOO- and bi-HCOO-); (iv) fast hydrogenation of formate species and conversion to CH3O- and CO; (v) continuous formation of CH3OH and CO. Fig. 13 depicts the reaction mechanism for methanol formation on the surface of Pd/CeO2 catalysts, which is in agreement with the findings of mechanistic investigations involving Pd based catalysts [29,41,65,74]. 3.5 Long-term catalyst performance Catalyst stability is an important issue for CO2 hydrogenation reaction both in terms of methanol synthesis and structure durability. Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst was tested for stable CO2 hydrogenation for 100 h of time on stream ( Fig. 14a). The catalyst showed slight loss of performance, i.e. a relative decrease of CO2 conversion of 10% was noted (average values of CO2 conversion, STY of methanol, and methanol selectivity in the examined time period were found to be 6.6%, 0.76 g/(gcat. h), and 63%, respectively). As determined by means of CHNS elemental analysis, the spent catalyst contained 3.8 wt% C. Following this result and considering that the fresh catalyst sample contained 0.7 wt% C, we calculated that approx. 0.06% of CO2 cumulatively converted in the period of 100 h, was transformed to coke. By performing mass balance calculations, 96% of C-containing species (including coke) were quantified. XRD analysis was performed to investigate the crystallinity of spent catalyst sample (Fig. 14b). The XRD pattern obtained after 100 h of time on stream shows a partial amorphous phase, which was not observed in case of fresh sample. This might be due to coke formation being of amorphous character as observed by means of SEM analysis. Further, the XRD pattern revealed the obvious formation of a small peak at 39.5° corresponding to (111) plane for Pd metallic phase, along with pure CeO2 phase. Moreover, the shift of peaks towards lower diffraction angles with increased lattice parameter (0.545 nm) was observed. The latter clearly indicated formation of mixed Ce-Pd compound due to insertion of Pd(0) (r = 137 pm) inside the ceria lattice (102 pm) [75]. All the above results confirm that the Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst shows sufficient stability without compromising activity and selectivity for the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. 4 Conclusions In summary, CeO2 supports of four different morphologies, i.e. polyhedral, rod, cube and polygonal, were successfully prepared by adopting the hydrothermal and co-precipitation methods. Pd metallic ensembles were impregnated on derived CeO2 supports by using the wet-impregnation method. The microscopic results show that different morphologies (with and without Pd) possessed differently exposed crystalline planes, which significantly influenced the catalytic activity in the process of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The relation between exposed crystalline planes, surface area, acidic-basic sites, redox properties, and catalytic activity has proved to be interdependent, with the influence of specific surface area on the behavior of Pd/CeO2 catalysts being more pronounced than the nature of exposed crystal facets. The trend for the catalytic activity was found as follows: Pd/CeO2-NPH ({111}+{110}) > Pd/CeO2-NR ({111}+{100}) > Pd/CeO2-NPG {111} > Pd/CeO2-NC {100}. Combining the results of N2 physisorption, XRD, Raman, CO2-TPD, Py-TPD, and H2-TPR analyses suggests that PdO and PdxCe1-xO2-δ linkages are present in the Pd/CeO2 catalysts, which have different interactions with different exposed planes. The Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst shows the highest specific surface area with exposed facets ({111}+{110}), responsible for the formation of more oxygen vacancy and higher extent of surface oxygen mobility, with enhanced reduction property and higher number of acidic-basic sites on the catalyst surface, which contributed to improved catalytic activity. In contrast, the Pd/CeO2-NC catalyst with exposed plane {100} and the lowest specific surface area showed low content of oxygen vacancy and the least reduction property and number of acidic-basic sites, which in turn resulted in poor catalytic activity and methanol selectivity. It should be noted that not only the exposed crystalline planes but also surface area are among the dominating factors for the catalytic CO2 hydrogenation reaction over Pd/CeO2 catalysts. In-situ DRIFTS examination provided clear evidence for the formate reaction pathway of methanol synthesis. From a mechanistic point of view, the decomposition of surface carbonate species resulted in the formation of formate, which was further hydrogenated to form crucial methoxy species followed by methanol and CO as reaction products. The DRIFTS analysis also confirmed that the Pd/CeO2-NPH catalyst showed high selectivity for methanol production and low selectivity for CO formation; however, the opposite was observed in the case of Pd/CeO2-NC catalyst. Both CO2-TPD and in-situ DRIFT studies proved weaker interaction of Pd/CeO2-NC with CO2, which may be the reason for its poor catalytic activity. The overall results provide better understanding of the effect of crystal structure and surface properties on the catalytic CO2 hydrogenation reaction. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is one of the important reactions for environmental-related applications. Pd/CeO2 catalysts with four different ceria morphologies, i.e. polyhedral, rod, cube and polygonal, and 5 wt% Pd loading were synthesized, and their catalytic characteristics and reaction mechanism were studied. Combining the results of N2 physisorption, XRD, Raman, CO2-TPD, Py-TPD and H2-TPR analyses suggests that PdO and PdxCe1−xO2-δ linkages are present in the Pd/CeO2 catalysts, which have different interactions with different exposed planes. Pd functionalized ceria with polyhedral morphology denoted as Pd/CeO2-NPH shows the highest specific surface area with exposed facets ({111}+{110}), responsible for the formation of more oxygen vacancy and higher extent of surface oxygen mobility, and higher number of acidic-basic sites on the catalysts surface, which contributed to improved catalytic activity and selectivity. XRD and Raman spectroscopy results revealed strong metal-support interactions for the most active catalyst by forming the PdxCe1−xO2-δ linkage, which improved the formation of surface oxygen vacancies and CO2 activation on the CeO2 support and promoted dissociation of H2 on the Pd metal. In-situ DRIFTS examination provided clear evidence for the formate reaction pathway of methanol synthesis. From a mechanistic point of view, the decomposition of surface carbonate species resulted in the formation of formate, which was further hydrogenated to form crucial methoxy species followed by methanol and CO as reaction products.
coredata.dc:title: Exploring the effect of morphology and surface properties of nanoshaped Pd/CeO2 catalysts on CO2 hydrogenation to methanol

dcterms:subject.$: in-situ DRIFTS catalytic reaction mechanism investigation
